net.sf.appia.core
Class Appia

java.lang.Object
  net.sf.appia.core.Appia

public class Appia
extends java.lang.Object

Appia main class.
This class has the static methods responsible for the execution of all Appias functionality.
It is this class that calls the EventSchedulers and therefore makes the entire Appia system run.
It also keeps the current TimerManager.

Version:
0.1
Author:
Alexandre Pinto
See Also:
EventScheduler

getTimerManager

public static TimerManager getTimerManager()
Get the current TimerManager.

Returns:
the current TimerManager

setTimerManager

public static void setTimerManager(TimerManager timerManager)
Set the TimerManager.
The current TimerManager will be stoped. The new TimerManager will be started.

Parameters:
timerManager - the new TimerManager

insertEventScheduler

public static void insertEventScheduler(EventScheduler eventScheduler)
Registers a new EventScheduler.
This method is called by Channel.start()

Parameters:
eventScheduler - the new EventScheduler

removeEventScheduler

public static void removeEventScheduler(EventScheduler eventScheduler)
Unregisters a EventScheduler.

Parameters:
eventScheduler - the EventScheduler to deregister. It does nothing if the given EventScheduler is not registered.

insertListenRequest

public static void insertListenRequest(ExternalEvent descriptor)
In the Java version this method does nothing.

removeListenRequest

public static void removeListenRequest(ExternalEvent descriptor)
In the Java version this method does nothing.

run

public static void run()
Starts Appia operation.
This method implements the infinite loop that calls the consumeEvent() method of the registered EventSchedulers.
It's this method that makes the Appia run.

insertedEvent

public static void insertedEvent()
Method used by any EventScheduler to signal that a new Event has been inserted.
The Appia keeps track of how many events exist in all the EventSchedulers, and if none exist it simply waits idle.
